awd_titl_txt: The Development Of A High Resolution Rainfall Record
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Christopher Lepre of the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Rutgers University (USA) will bring his geological and anthropological expertise to East Africa in order to study the impact of past climate on the evolution of the human lineage. The ancient monsoon and its effect on African ecosystems is thought to be responsible for a number of significant turning points in the evolution of early humans. Nevertheless, there is a lack of high-resolution and long-term information about the amount of rain that fell over East Africa during the interval between 4.0 and 1.0 million years ago. This has obscured understanding of how climate changes may have influenced early human anatomy, the development of stone tools, and dietary habits. To address this problem, the prehistoric rainfall of northwest Kenya will be reconstructed by using geological fieldwork and laboratory analyses of ancient soils.  These ancient soils directly encase important fossils and archaeological sites that document the oldest stone tools in the world that are currently known, in addition to the evolutionary history of such species as Homo erectus and Homo habilis.  Further objectives of the project are to train Kenyan professionals in laboratory research methods and develop a mobile teaching project through the Rutgers Geology Museum that provides schools in the United States and Kenya with hands-on opportunities for learning about fossils, archaeology, and geology.The research project will provide the scientific community with an advanced understanding of Earth's ancient climate and methods of reconstruction, highlight the importance of Kenya for interpreting the human past, and strengthen the collaborations between the National Museums of Kenya and the United States.

The research of Dr. Lepre concentrates on the longstanding questions: Why was there such a diversity of human evolutionary events during the timeframe of 4.0-1.0 million years ago, and how did the environment contribute to these events?  He will address these questions by analyzing the iron-bearing minerals preserved in ancient soils.  Such minerals, like hematite and goethite, are formed under certain temperature conditions and specific quantities of yearly rainfall.  Through assessing the ratio of hematite to goethite in ancient soils, past environmental changes due to climate can be reconstructed and compared with events of human evolution. Dr. Lepre's laboratory at Rutgers University is equipped with a spectrophotometer that can detect hematite and goethite in soil samples through measuring the diffuse reflectance of light.  As these minerals contain iron, additional measurements of the magnetic properties of the samples will help elucidate the environmental conditions under which the ancient soils formed.  Geologic fieldwork will be conducted at the Lake Turkana Basin, a geographically remote but world-renowned fossil and archaeological locality in northwest Kenya.  This multidisciplinary research applies new methods towards the analysis of ancient soils of the Lake Turkana Basin in an attempt to answer old questions about the environment of human evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Development of a High-Resolution Rainfall Record was designed to test hypotheses about how the environment and early human evolution may have intersected. The project partnered with the Education Department of the National Museums of Kenya to develop new outreach activities that provide primary school students with opportunities to learn about Earth science and paleoanthropology.

 

Two fieldwork seasons occurred at the Pliocene-Pleistocene strata surrounding Lake Turkana, Kenya. At this world-renowned hominin site, the project assessed  iron-oxide minerals in ancient soils and if the minerals indicate paleoclimate conditions. Fieldwork examined paleogeographic areas on the northeast, northwest, and southwest side of the lake. Collected samples were analyzed in the laboratory using diffuse reflectance spectrometry, rock magnetic measurements, and X-ray fluorescence. Samples were taken from sites that preserved some of the earliest evidence for human bipedal walking, as represented by Australopithecus anamnesis, some of the oldest evidence of stone hand-axes and Homo erectus, and the oldest stone tools in the world currently known.

 

Each paleogeographic area of the basin had a somewhat unique association of ancient soil minerals. The paleogeographic distribution of iron oxides will improve understanding of existing sedimentary models and inform geophysical/paleomagnetic studies as to how iron-bearing minerals are partitioned within half-graben depositional basins. It was determined that a yet unrecognized mode of soil iron oxide formation may be typical of the East African monsoonal climate. Other studies of soil iron oxides from seasonal climates predict that the concentration of soil hematite increase proportional with fine-grained ferrimagnetic minerals. No such relationship was found with the ancient soils from Turkana. These ancient Turkana soils also differed from modern soils formed in the Laikipia region of Kenya, suggesting that at about four million years ago, parts of the basin where some of the earliest bipedal hominins were evolving experienced hotter and drier seasonal conditions as compared to high-altitude savanna environments on the flanks of the modern Kenya rift valley.

 

East African hominin evolution is linked to global paleoclimate, notably ice-age climates and orbital controls on tropical insolation. This project suggested that the tropical ocean-atmospheric system known as Walker Circulation also had a great impact. At ~2 Myr, Walker Circulation established a dry adaptive context in which H. erectus and Acheulian stone tools first appeared in eastern Africa. Also, the project helped to identify a transient directional change towards less dry conditions coinciding with the extinction of Paranthropus boisei from eastern Africa. Ultimately, it appears  that environmental variability had a minimal influence on Pleistocene events of hominin evolution. These findings refute long-standing ideas that increased variability (rather than directional environmental change) selected for key adaptive traits, like bipedality, enlarged brain sizes, meat eating and new stone tools, in the human lineage.

 

The broader impacts of the project were made successful through partnerships with the Educational Department of the National Museums of Kenya. These partnerships engaged primary school students of Kenya with new hands-on instructional activities for young visitors to the museums. Activities were structured to fulfill the needs of a variety of age groups between 5 and 12 years old. Simple experiments, demonstrations, and the handling of specimens were used to make the information accessible to the students. Activities were modified for online formats during the COVID-19 Pandemic and are still implemented today for reaching primary school students unable to travel to the museums. Education experts from the National Museums shared strategies and techniques for instructing primary school students and the project shared knowledge about rocks, minerals, and the prehistory of Kenya. These strategies and techniques were used by the project to engage in online teaching for the Rutgers University Geology Museum.

 

The project held public town meetings withs residents of Lake Turkana communities to discuss how climate change may impact water sustainability. Public lectures about the monsoonal climate of Kenya were given at the National Museums in Nairobi. Ideas were exchanged with Kenyan students and museum interns, and new relationships were made for recruiting potential Kenyan graduate students. Five new collaborators for future projects in Kenya were established.

 

The project helped the principal investigator (PI) to advance their career by moving to a new institution and accepting a tenure-track appointment as an assistant professor of geology. This involved building a new lab and assuming leadership roles in existing ones. Two students (one graduate and one undergraduate) at the new institution are contributing to ongoing analyses affiliated with the project goals. The PI has fostered new relationships with Kenyan academics at the new institution. Plans have been organized to collaborate on identifying potential Kenyan graduate students. It is intended that future projects will be the first of several collaborations that will help to address the dearth of Kenyan representation in international Earth science communities. Kenyan students will be recruited to participate in further research on paleoclimate and human origins.
